(2014–present) | signature = | website = | footnotes = | current_members = | past_members = }} '''Susan Elizabeth Perkins''' (born 22 September 1969) is an English comedian, broadcaster, actress, and writer. Originally coming to prominence through her comedy partnership with [[Mel Giedroyc]] in ''[[Mel and Sue]]'', she has since become best known as a radio broadcaster and television presenter, notably of ''[[The Great British Bake Off]]'' (2010–2016) and ''[[Insert Name Here]]'' (2016–present). She was ranked sixth in ''[[The Independent on Sunday]]''{{'}}s 2014 [[Rainbow List]].{{cite news|title=Rainbow List 2014, 1 to 101|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/therainbowlist/rainbow-list-2014-1-to-100-9848457.html|accessdate=28 November 2014|newspaper=The Independent on Sunday|date=9 November 2014|location=London}} *{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/the-independent-on-sundays-pink-list-2013-8876183.html|title=The Independent on Sunday's Pink List 2013|date=13 October 2013|accessdate=19 November 2013|newspaper=The Independent on Sunday|location=London}} *{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/the-ios-pink-list-2012-8216187.html|title=The IoS Pink List 2012|date=4 November 2012|accessdate=19 November 2013|newspaper=The Independent on Sunday|location=London}} *{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/the-ios-pink-list-2011-2374595.html|date=23 October 2011|title=The IoS Pink List 2011|accessdate=19 November 2013|newspaper=The Independent on Sunday|location=London|first=Ian|last=Herbert}} *{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/the-iiosi-pink-list-2010-2040472.html|title=The ''IoS'' Pink List 2010|date=1 August 2010|newspaper=The Independent on Sunday|accessdate=19 November 2013|location=London}} *{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/the-iiosi-pink-list-2008-852032.html|title=The ''IoS'' pink list 2008|date=22 June 2008|newspaper=The Independent on Sunday|accessdate=19 November 2013|location=London}} ==Early life and education== Perkins was born on 22 September 1969 in south London, where she grew up in [[Croydon]] with her two younger siblings and parents. Her father worked for a local car dealer and her mother was employed as a secretary.{{cite news | title= The Observer Profile: Sue Perkins – Bake Off host under fire|url= https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/apr/19/sue-perkins-bake-off-host-feels-heat | last= Anthony| first= Andrew| date= 19 April 2015 | newspaper= ''[[The Observer]]'' | page= 34| accessdate= 20 April 2015}} She was educated at [[Croham Hurst School]], a nearby independent school for girls in [[South Croydon]], [[Greater London]], at the same time as television presenter [[Susanna Reid]].[https://archive.is/20120724145709/http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediaselector/check/player/nol/newsid_4710000/newsid_4714300?redirect=4714375.stm&news=1&nbwm=1&nbram=1&bbwm=1&bbram=1&asb=1 BBC Breakfast interview with Sue Perkins on 25 July 2005] She later studied English at New Hall (now [[Murray Edwards College]]) at the [[University of Cambridge]], graduating in 1991. While at Cambridge, she was a member of the [[Footlights]], where she met [[Mel Giedroyc]].{{cite news | url= https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/how-we-met-mel-giedroyc-and-sue-perkins-1046300.html | title= How We Met: Mel Giedroyc And Sue Perkins | location=London | work=The Independent | date=10 January 1999}} She was Footlights president during the academic year 1990–91.{{cite web|url=http://footlights.org/alumni-archive?name=1990-1999 |title=Footlight alumni 1990-1999 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015035204/http://footlights.org/alumni-archive?name=1990-1999 |archivedate=15 October 2012 |df= }} ==Mel and Sue== Perkins and creative partner [[Mel Giedroyc]] took their first steps into television under the name [[Mel and Sue]]. The duo began to gain success and were short-listed for the ''[[Daily Express]]'' Best Newcomers award at the [[Edinburgh Festival]] in 1993. After a few years writing for [[French & Saunders]] (and occasionally appearing on their BBC series), they co-hosted a lunchtime show on [[Channel 4]] entitled ''[[Light Lunch]]'', and an early evening version, ''[[Light Lunch|Late Lunch]]'', which ran from March 1997 to February 1998. In January 2015, Giedroyc and Perkins began hosting their own daytime chat show on [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] called ''[[Mel and Sue (TV series)|Mel and Sue]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2014/aug/14/great-british-bake-off-mel-giedroyc-sue-perkins|title=Great British Bake Off stars clinch ITV chat show|work=the Guardian|accessdate=18 November 2014}}[http://www.itv.com/beontv/shows/melandsue] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141204202412/http://www.itv.com/beontv/shows/melandsue|date=4 December 2014}} In August 2015, it was announced that ''[[Mel and Sue (TV series)|Mel and Sue]]'' had been cancelled by ITV.[http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a662812/mel--sues-daytime-chatshow-has-been-dropped-by-itv.html#~pl3QvsuXbrYDmx Mel & Sue's daytime chatshow has been dropped by ITV - TV News - Digital Spy] On 23 July 2017, it was confirmed that they would host a new version of ''[[The Generation Game]]'' for BBC One.{{cite web|url=http://www.live.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2017/the-generation-game|title=Mel and Sue are bringing The Generation Game back to BBC One|publisher=BBC Media Centre|accessdate=23 July 2017}} ==Television== In 2002, Perkins appeared on the [[Celebrity Big Brother 2 (UK)|second UK series]] of ''[[Celebrity Big Brother (UK)|Celebrity Big Brother]]'' in aid of four charities, [[Centrepoint (charity)|Centrepoint]], [[Missing People|National Missing Persons Helpline]], [[Rethink Mental Illness|Rethink]] and [[Samaritans (charity)|Samaritans]]. During the series, she interacted with series winner [[Mark Owen]] from [[Take That]], and TV presenter [[Les Dennis]]. Perkins was evicted from the house on Day 9.{{cite news|title=Sue gets Big Brother shove|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/2523569.stm|publisher=BBC|accessdate=19 February 2013|date=28 November 2002}} She provided the voice for Messenger Bird in ''[[Dinotopia]]'', produced for Hallmark Entertainment.{{cite web|title=Full cast and crew for "Dinotopia"|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0310443/fullcredits?ref_=tt_cl_sm#cast|publisher=imdb.com|accessdate=20 February 2013}} In 2003, Perkins joined Channel 4 morning television programme ''[[RI:SE]]''.{{cite news|last=Deans|first=Jason|title=Mel and Sue join RI:SE|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2003/jan/16/broadcasting.channel4|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=19 February 2013|location=London|date=16 January 2003}} In the same year, Perkins also provided additional written material for BBC sitcom ''[[Absolutely Fabulous]]''. Perkins has appeared on several BBC shows including ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'', ''[[Mock the Week]]'', ''[[QI]]'', ''[[Room 101 (TV series)|Room 101]]'', ''[[The Weakest Link (UK game show)|Celebrity Weakest Link]]'', ''[[Question Time (TV series)|Question Time]]'' and ''[[Newsnight]]''. Perkins has commented that the BBC pay her a regular wage for "blabbering on random shows".{{Citation needed|date=February 2013}} She has made appearances as a field reporter for [[Armando Iannucci]] vehicle ''[[The Saturday Night Armistice]]''. Perkins hosted the second series of ''Good Evening, Rockall'', a short-lived, news-orientated panel game shown on [[BBC Choice]]. In 2006, she appeared in [[BBC Four]]'s vocabulary quiz show ''[[Never Mind the Full Stops]]''. She was also a team captain on [[ITV Network|ITV]]'s ''Win, Lose or Draw Late''. During the same decade she made appearances on ''[[Celebrity MasterChef]]'', ''Celebrity Poker'' and ''[[News Knight with Sir Trevor McDonald]]''. In April 2007, she participated in the television series, ''Edwardian Supersize Me'' for the BBC. She was joined by food critic [[Giles Coren]]. The series focused on spending a week eating the equivalent of a wealthy Edwardian couple's food, whilst wearing period clothing. Following the series, Perkins and Coren were commissioned to present a new series called, ''[[The Supersizers Go...]]''. The premise of "Edwardian Supersize Me" was replicated and focused on other periods throughout history. In the first episode, they survived for a week on [[Second World War]] rations. It was re-commissioned for a second episode, Perkins and Coren covered the [[English Restoration]] period. The third episode covered the Victorian period, the fourth the 1970s, the fifth the [[Elizabethan era|Elizabethan]] period and the sixth the [[Regency era|Regency]] period. In August and September 2008, Perkins appeared in the reality television series ''[[Maestro (TV series)|Maestro]]'' on [[BBC Two]]. During the series, a group of eight celebrities attempted (until eliminated) to learn to conduct orchestral, choral and operatic music.{{cite web|title=Profile: Sue Perkins|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/musictv/maestro/whos-who/the-students/sue-perkins/|publisher=BBC|accessdate=19 February 2013}} During the series, Perkins conducted three pieces, two of them with soprano soloist [[Lesley Garrett]].{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/musictv/maestro/news/sue-takes-hyde-park-by-storm/ |title=Sue Perkins takes Hyde Park by Storm |date=13 September 2008 |accessdate=22 April 2012}} Perkins won the series.{{cite web|title=Congratulations to Sue Perkins!|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/musictv/maestro/news/congratulations-to-sue-perkins/|publisher=BBC|accessdate=19 February 2013}} In 2008, Perkins narrated the series ''[[....And Proud]]'' on [[Virgin 1]]. Perkins appeared in a second "Supersizers" series called ''The Supersizers Eat...'' with Giles Coren which aired on [[BBC Two]] in June and July 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2009/04_april/22/bbctwo_os.shtml |title=Press Office - BBC Two Spring/Summer 2009: Programmes O-S |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=27 April 2009}} In September and October 2009 she hosted the Channel 4 panel game ''The Big Food Fight''. She then gave a televised lecture for the [[Royal Television Society]]. Entitled "Wit's End? British Comedy at the Crossroads", the lecture focused on the state of British comedy. The presentation was broadcast on BBC Two.{{cite web|title=Huw Wheldon Lecture 2009: Wit's End? British Comedy at the Crossroads|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00f719s|publisher=BBC|accessdate=20 February 2013}} In March 2010, Perkins appeared in a three part mini-series on BBC Two, ''A Band for Britain'', in which she attempted to revive the fortunes of the [[Dinnington Colliery Band]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00rhghl/episodes/guide |title=A Band for Britain: Episode guide |accessdate=22 April 2012}}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/bbc/7377444/Sue-Perkins-on-A-Band-for-Britain.html |title=Sue Perkins on a Band for Britain |last=West |first=Naomi |newspaper=The Telegraph |date=5 March 2010 |accessdate=22 April 2012 |location=London}} In 2010, Perkins and Coren presented ''Giles and Sue Live the Good Life'', a celebration of the 1970s BBC series ''[[The Good Life (1975 TV series)|The Good Life]]'', where they were challenged to live a self-sufficient lifestyle.{{cite web|title=Giles and Sue Live The Good Life|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00w08q9|publisher=BBC|accessdate=19 February 2013}} Later that year, Perkins was joined by [[Mel Giedroyc]] to present ''[[The Great British Bake Off]]''.{{cite web|title=Judges and Presenters|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b013pqnm/profiles/judges-and-presenters|publisher=BBC|accessdate=19 February 2013}} The series is a cookery competition with each episode looking at a different aspect of baking which they co-hosted for seven seasons. In September 2016, Love Productions announced that a three-year deal had been agreed to broadcast the show on [[Channel 4]] instead of the BBC from 2017.{{cite web|last = Halls|first = Andy|date = 12 September 2016|url = https://www.thesun.co.uk/tvandshowbiz/1771204/great-british-bake-off-to-move-from-bbc-to-channel-4-after-exhaustive-talks-break-down|title = Great British Bake Off to move from BBC to Channel 4 after 'exhaustive' talks break down|newspaper = [[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]|accessdate = 12 September 2016}}{{cite news|url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/09/12/bbc-loses-great-british-bake-off/|title = BBC loses Great British Bake Off, as Channel 4 swoops for corporation's biggest show|last = Foster|first = Patrick|date = 12 September 2016|newspaper = [[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate = 12 September 2016}} Perkins and Giedroyc announced that they would not be continuing with Bake Off on its new network.{{cite news|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-37355065|title = Great British Bake Off: Mel and Sue to quit as hosts|date = 13 September 2016|newspaper = [[BBC News]]|accessdate = 13 September 2016}} [[Mary Berry]] announced she was also leaving Bake Off{{cite news|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-37437907|title = Mary Berry to leave Bake Off ahead of Channel 4 move|date = 22 September 2016|newspaper = [[BBC News]]|accessdate = 22 September 2016}} on the same day that fellow-judge [[Paul Hollywood]] separately announced he would be staying with the show.{{cite news|url = https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/sep/22/mary-berry-leave-great-british-bake-off-paul-hollywood-bbc-mel-giedroyc-sue-perkins|title = Mary Berry to leave Bake Off – but Paul Hollywood agrees to stay|first = Jane|last = Martinson|date = 22 September 2016|accessdate = 23 September 2016|newspaper = [[The Guardian]]}} Perkins narrated the 2011 game show ''[[Don't Scare the Hare]]''. In October 2011, she presented a series on BBC Two called ''All Roads Lead Home''. It featured Perkins learning how to use nature as a navigation tool. She was joined on the series by [[Alison Steadman]] and [[Stephen Mangan]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b012yq4v|title=All Roads Lead Home|publisher=BBC|accessdate=6 October 2011}} On 30 December 2011, she presented and performed ''Mrs Dickens's Family Christmas'', a sixty-minute documentary for BBC Two that examined the marriage of [[Charles Dickens]] through the eyes of his wife, [[Catherine Dickens|Catherine]]. Periodically, she has presented ''[[The Culture Show]]'',{{cite web|title=Sue Perkins The Culture Show|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b006t6c5/presenters/sueperkins|publisher=BBC|accessdate=19 February 2013}} including its broadcast from the [[Edinburgh Festival]] in August 2012. During that broadcast she interviewed [[Nile Rodgers]], a member of the American disco pop music group [[Chic (band)|Chic]]. In 2011, Perkins featured in the BBC travel adventure show ''[[World's Most Dangerous Roads]]: Alaska''. She and [[Charley Boorman]], her companion for the trip, drove the [[Dalton Highway]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b014hnld|title=BBC World's Most Dangerous Roads series 1|publisher=BBC|accessdate=16 September 2012}} She then appeared with [[Liza Tarbuck]] in Series 2 Episode 2 of ''World's Most Dangerous Roads: Ho Chi Minh Trail'', shown in 2012, driving in [[Vietnam]] and [[Laos]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01l3bg9|title=BBC World's Most Dangerous Roads series 2|publisher=BBC|accessdate=16 September 2012}} In November 2014 she returned to South-East Asia, travelling from the Mekong delta up to Tibet in ''The Mekong River with Sue Perkins'', produced by Indus Films for the BBC. In September 2015, she presented a one-off show ''[[Kolkata]] with Sue Perkins'' on BBC One. On 26 February 2013, the first episode of Perkins's self-penned sitcom, ''[[Heading Out]]'' was broadcast.{{cite web|title=Heading Out New six-part comedy for BBC Two penned by Sue Perkins|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/mediapacks/headingout/|publisher=BBC|accessdate=20 February 2013}} Produced by Red Production Company and Square Peg TV, Perkins also portrayed the show's lead, Sara.{{cite web|title=Sue Perkins to star in self-penned sitcom for BBC Two|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2012/heading-out.html|publisher=BBC|accessdate=20 February 2013}} From 4 August 2014, she presented ''Cooks' Questions'' on [[More4]].{{cite news|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2014-08-04/sue-perkins-on-cooks-questions-ive-got-none-of-david-dimblebys-sense-of-cool|title=Sue Perkins on Cooks' Questions: "I've got none of David Dimbleby's sense of cool"|last=Lazarus|first=Susanna|date=4 August 2014|accessdate=10 April 2015|newspaper=[[Radio Times]]|publisher=[[Immediate Media Company|Immediate Media]]}} Perkins was a team captain on the second and third series of ''[[What the Dickens?]]'', hosted by [[Sandi Toksvig]] on [[Sky Arts]]. In 2016, she began hosting the [[BBC Two]] panel show ''[[Insert Name Here]]'' and commentated on the [[BBC]] game show ''[[Can't Touch This (game show)|Can't Touch This]]''. She co-presented ''[[The Big Spell (TV series)|The Big Spell]]'', a weekly game show for [[Sky1]] alongside [[Joe Lycett]] and [[Moira Stuart]].https://www.expressandstar.com/entertainment/showbiz-news/2016/07/15/sue-perkins-to-team-up-with-joe-lycett-and-moira-stuart-for-sky-1-spelling-show/ ==Conducting== Following her success in ''Maestro'', Perkins guest-conducted the London Lesbian/Gay Symphony Orchestra on 11 October 2009, at [[St Anne's Church, Soho|St Anne's Church]] Garden in Soho. She conducted two pieces, the Simpsons Theme by [[Danny Elfman]], and the [[William Tell Overture]] by [[Rossini]], the latter for the first time. {{cite web |url=http://www.divamag.co.uk/diva/arts_reviews_detail.asp?a=6024 |title=LIVE MUSIC: Sue Perkins and the Gay & Lesbian Symphony Orchestra |publisher=[[Diva (magazine)|Diva]] |accessdate=1 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101222040233/http://www.divamag.co.uk/diva/arts_reviews_detail.asp?a=6024 |archivedate=22 December 2010 |df=dmy }} {{cite web |url=http://lavidalondon.wordpress.com/2009/10/12/lastloveliest/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121225212043/http://lavidalondon.wordpress.com/2009/10/12/lastloveliest/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=25 December 2012 |title=The Year’s Last, Loveliest Smile |date=12 October 2009 |work=Livin' La Vida London |publisher=[[WordPress.com]] }} As part of ''A Band for Britain'', Perkins conducted the Dinnington Colliery Band at the [[DW Stadium]] playing the National Anthem for a [[Rugby League Four Nations|Four Nations]] rugby match, {{cite web |url=http://www.superleague.co.uk/article.php?id=15812 |title=engage Super League website |accessdate=30 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120825215448/http://www.superleague.co.uk/article.php?id=15812 |archivedate=25 August 2012 |df=dmy }} and also conducted them together with the [[Grimethorpe Colliery Band]] at [[Sheffield City Hall]].{{cite news |url=http://www.metro.co.uk/metrolife/818598-a-band-for-britain-doesnt-hit-the-right-notes |title=A Band For Britain doesn't hit the right notes |last=Williams |first=Andrew |newspaper=Metro |date=22 March 2010 |accessdate=22 April 2012}} Perkins again conducted the BBC Concert Orchestra at the first [[Comedy Prom]] at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] during the 2011 Prom season. {{cite web |url=http://www.theartsdesk.com/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=4326:bbc-proms-tim-minchin-kit-and-the-widow-beardyman-bbc-concert-orchestra&Itemid=27 |title=BBC Proms: Tim Minchin, Kit and the Widow, Beardyman, BBC Concert Orchestra |date=14 August 2011 |accessdate=5 September 2011 }} ==Radio== Perkins is a panel member on Radio 4's ''[[The News Quiz]]'' and has made regular appearances on [[BBC Radio 2|Radio 2]]'s ''[[It's Been a Bad Week]]''. She is also a frequent panellist on another popular Radio 4 show, ''[[Just a Minute]]'': in the 2012 television version, she appeared in four out of the 10 episodes (more than any other panellist except [[Paul Merton]] who appeared in all 10) and won on all four occasions.{{cite web|url=http://just-a-minute.info/jamtv4.html|title=Just a Minute! Television Season 4|accessdate=10 April 2012}} She was the chairman of [[BBC Radio 4|Radio 4]]'s ''[[The 99p Challenge]]'' until the show finished in 2004. Perkins appeared every day in the last half hour of [[Mark Radcliffe]]'s afternoon radio show on Radio 2, when he sat in for [[Steve Wright (DJ)|Steve Wright]]. Since 2006, Perkins has been a panellist on a Radio 4 show, ''The Personality Test'', a quiz show about the host, presented by a different host each week. Past hosts include [[Gyles Brandreth]] and [[Rick Wakeman]], and other panellists include [[Robin Ince]], [[Lucy Porter]] and [[Will Smith (comedian)|Will Smith]]. Perkins is a regular cast member of [[Count Arthur Strong]]'s Radio Show. Perkins presented a Radio 4 documentary on the [[Lake District]]'s competition the "[[World's Biggest Liar]]", which she won.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/cumbria/6159642.stm Comedienne crowned biggest liar], BBC News Online, Cumbria, 17 November 2006. Retrieved 22 June 2008. In December 2008, she was a guest on ''[[Private Passions]]'', the biographical music discussion programme on [[BBC Radio 3]].[http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio3/privatepassions/ BBC Radio 3] Perkins was also chairman of the Radio 4 panel game ''Dilemma'', in which four humorous guests discussed moral conundrums she provided for them. The first series ran for six episodes on Sunday evenings from 13 November to 18 December 2011. Another series of this programme ran in February 2013. On 9 July 2017 Perkins was the guest celebrity on Radio 4's Desert Island Discs. ==Books== Perkins was a judge for the 2009 [[Man Booker Prize]].{{cite web|url=http://www.themanbookerprize.com/prize/thisyear/judges |title=Man Booker 2009 judges |work= |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090702131332/http://www.themanbookerprize.com/prize/thisyear/judges |archivedate=2 July 2009 }} Perkins's memoir, ''Spectacles'', was published in October 2015.{{cite book|author=Sue Perkins|title=Spectacles|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oM2kCQAAQBAJ|date=8 October 2015|publisher=Penguin Books Limited|isbn=978-1-4059-1857-2}} ==Edinburgh Festival appearances== Perkins has performed two stand-up comedy solo shows at the [[Edinburgh Fringe]] Festival: ''Spectacle Wearer Of The Year 2006'' in 2005, and ''The Disappointing Second Show'' in 2006. ==Personal life== In August 2012, Perkins appeared on ''[[Tatler]]''{{'}}s list of high-profile lesbians in London.{{cite web|url=http://www.tatler.com/news/articles/july-2012/lesbian-shoot-video|date=5 July 2012|accessdate=10 April 2015|title=Tatler Film: Behind the scenes of our lesbian shoot|quote=We're out-and-out proud to present seven of London's smartest and loveliest lesbians in our August issue!|work=[[Tatler]]|publisher=[[Condé Nast]]}}{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/tatler-lesbians-issue-sue-perkins-emma-kennedy-359580|title=Tatler Backs Seven High-Profile Lesbians with Special Issue|last=Edmondson|first=Nicholas|date=4 July 2012|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|accessdate=10 April 2015}} She was outed as a lesbian in 2002 by her ex-girlfriend [[Rhona Cameron]] during Cameron's appearance on [[ITV Network|ITV]]'s ''[[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! (UK series 1)|I'm a Celebrity... Get Me Out of Here!]]''{{Cite news |title=Thank you, reality TV |first=Jenny |last=White |date=7 November 2003 |accessdate=31 December 2007 |periodical=[[The Guardian]] |url=https://www.theguardian.com/women/story/0,3604,1079618,00.html | location=London}} She has said that “being a lesbian is only about the 47th most interesting thing about me”. In April 2015, Perkins was the victim of cyberbullying on Twitter after bookmakers made her the favourite to fill the vacancy on the BBC's ''[[Top Gear (2002 TV series)|Top Gear]]'' programme left by the departure of [[Jeremy Clarkson]], despite Perkins saying that rumours about her imminent appointment to the show were "fabricated". She temporarily quit the social media site, but returned in August 2015. In September 2015, Perkins revealed that she was diagnosed with [[prolactinoma]], which is a benign growth on her [[pituitary gland]]. Perkins received the diagnosis eight years previously. The side effects prevent her from having children.{{cite news |last= Quinn |first= Ben |title= Sue Perkins, star of Great British Bake Off, tells of eight-year brain tumour |url= https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/sep/02/great-british-bake-off-sue-perkins-brain-tumour| date= 2 September 2015 |newspaper= [[The Guardian]] |location= London| accessdate= 2 September 2015 }}{{cite web |last= Fallon |first= Bernadette |title= Sue Perkins: living with a brain tumour |url= http://www.goodhousekeeping.co.uk/lifestyle/gh-women-celebrity-interviews/sue-perkins| date= 2 September 2015 |work= [[Good Housekeeping| Good Housekeeping (UK edition)]] |location=London| accessdate= 2 September 2015 }} Perkins was brought up as a [[Roman Catholic]]{{cite web|title=Sue Perkins rekindles her love of music|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2012-01-24/sue-perkins-rekindles-her-love-of-music/|publisher=Radio Times|date=24 January 2012}} and lives in London and [[Cornwall]].{{cite web|title=The Tatler List - 153|url=http://www.tatler.com/the-tatler-list/p/sue-perkins|publisher=Tatler|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150801215508/http://www.tatler.com/the-tatler-list/p/sue-perkins|archivedate=1 August 2015|df=dmy-all}} ==Filmography== ===Television=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#b0c4de; text-align:center;" !
